name.text: 25.3.2.3 Method of separation of variables - general approach

questiontext.text:
Wave equation
\(\qquad\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}=\dfrac{1}{c^2}\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial t^2}\) \((6)\)

Example

By following a similar procedure to the above, assume a product solution

\(\qquad\displaystyle u(x,t)=X(x)T(t)\)

for the wave equation and find the two ODEs satisfied by \(X(x)\) and \(T(t)\).

  1. First obtain \(\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}\) and \(\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial t^2}\):
  2. Now substitute these results into \((6)\) and transpose so the variables are separated i.e. all functions of \(x\) are on the left-hand side, all funtions of \(t\) on the right-hand side:
  3. Finally, write down the required ordinary differential equations:

Solution

  1. \( u=X(x)T(t)\) gives \(\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}=X''T\) and \(\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial t^2}=XT''\)
  2. We get \(X''T= \dfrac{1}{c^2}XT''\) and, transposing, \(\dfrac{X''}{X}=\dfrac{1}{c^2} \dfrac{T''}{T}\)
  3. Equating both sides to the same constant \(K\) gives

    \(\qquad \dfrac{X''}{X}=K\) or \(\dfrac{d^2X}{dx^2}-KX=0\)

    and

    \(\qquad \dfrac{1}{c^2} \dfrac{T''}{T}=K \qquad\) or \(\qquad \dfrac{d^2 T}{dt^2}-Kc^2T=0\)
The solution of the ODEs \((7)\) and \((8)\) has been obtained earlier, and will depend on the sign of \(K\).
